bestBHT.bht: When faced with urgency, swift action is required, as seen in the instruction given. Those on the housetop should refrain from entering the house or gathering belongings. This vivid imagery emphasizes the criticality of the situation. The mention of the housetop highlights the need to take external steps, underscoring the urgency. It is a call for immediate action, leaving no room for delay or distraction, but rather a focused response to the impending danger.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Let him that is on the housetop not get down into the house, neither enter therein, to take any thing out of his house—that is, let him take the outside flight of steps from the roof to the ground; a graphic way of denoting the extreme urgency of the case...
Albert Barnes: On the house-top - See the notes at Matthew 9:1-8.
John Gill: And let him that is on the house top, not go down into the house."

The commentators also point out that the phrase on the housetop refers to taking the outside flight of steps from the roof to the ground, further emphasizing the urgency of the situation.
